references: In this section, we present important preliminaries and introduce local importance sampling into FL. We will then sketch the basic idea and the framework of ISFL. Some key notations are listed in Table I.

S5.T2.caption: TABLE II: Basic experiment settings.
S5.T2.table:
Parameter Value
Number of clients K𝐾K 20
Maximum global epoch TGsubscript𝑇𝐺T_{G} 25
Federated period Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} 5
Training batch size ℬℬ\mathcal{B} 128
Learning rate η𝜂\eta 1e-3
Non-i.i.d. ratio N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R 0.95 & 0.98
Volume for gradient Lipschitz updating |𝒟L|subscript𝒟𝐿|\mathcal{D}_{L}| 500
references: In the basic experiments, we consider an FL system with 20 clients which fully participate the aggregation. The detailed settings and learning configurations are listed in Table II. We set the maximum global epoch as 25, respectively. During each global epoch, clients train their models locally for 5 epochs. The local data of each client are divided into batches with size of 128 to carry the mini-batch SGD training. Besides, we update the gradient Lipschitz using a small dataset 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} by (8) with 500 samples randomly selected from the unused dataset.

S5.T3.caption: TABLE III: The numerical comparison of different learning schemes.
S5.T3.table:
Schemes Accuracy on 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} / 𝒟Gsubscript𝒟𝐺\mathcal{D}_{G} (%)
N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.95 N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.98
Centralized model 80.90 / - 79.36 / -
FedAvg 63.38 / 66.25 38.39 / 44.47
GradNorm-IS 48.14 / 49.49 44.67 / 47.17
RW-IS 66.10 / 69.64 56.05 / 64.97
ISFL-ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi=0.05 73.46 / 79.33 68.58 / 78.25
ISFL-ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi=0.01 72.18 / 79.23 69.39 / 77.33
references: We test two different non-i.i.d. data split settings with N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.95 and N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.98. The local data distributions are shown in Fig. 4(a) and 4(d). To evaluate the performance of several training settings and methods, we compare ISFL with the original FL algorithm FedAvg and two sampling based schemes. The accuracy comparisons of different learning schemes on 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Gsubscript𝒟𝐺\mathcal{D}_{G} are presented in Fig. 4(b) and 4(e) and the numerical results are listed in Table III. One can observe that for the non-i.i.d. data, both FedAvg and GradNorm-IS perform poorly in terms of accuracy, convergence, and stability. It is worthy to be noted that though gradient-norm based importance sampling was proved to improve the non-i.i.d. FL for regression models [32], such scheme seems not well compatible with the neural network models which do not satisfy the convexity assumption of loss functions. Specifically, assigning higher weights to the data sample with larger gradient norm cannot effectively reduce the divergence of local SGD while employing the NN models. Such phenomena will be explained in detail through the sampling weight discussions later. In contrast, RW-IS efficiently improves the accuracy under two N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R data settings and performs well on stability. Furthermore, ISFL enhances about 10% / 30% accuracy respectively under two non-i.i.d. data splits. Most notably, as listed in Table III, ISFL nearly reaches the centralized model (trained on the integration of the distributed data) with about 7% and 10% lower accuracy on standard CIFAR-10 test data. We deem that ISFL also narrows the performance gap between FL and centralized learning.

As for the setting of the lowest IS weight ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi, we test the ISFL schemes under ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi=0.05 and ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi=0.01. The results in Table III imply that different ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi lead to similar model performance. Such outcome is comprehensible since we set ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi as a small constant in the constraints (14a) of 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} to ensure that all categories could contribute to the federated model at least in a low proportion. Moreover, according to the water-filling solution in Theorem 3, the optimal IS probability is only related to the minimal of ΓΓ\Gamma. Thus, the small value of ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi influence little on ISFL performance.
